results.title: War without weapons
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy Productions, Film Australia, Peter Johnston and Curtis Levy
results.brief_description: A behind the scenes look at the Victorian Football League team, North Melbourne, and the preparation and physical build up that goes into getting a team ready for the top Australian Rules Football competition. Ron Barassi, from North Melbourne, is shown in his role as a top VFL coach and we follow the team through its early training sessions to the opening match of the season. Looks at some of the spectacular action from the North Melbourne/Carlton challenge in 1979.

results.title: War requiem
results.creator_credit: Anglo International Films, British Broadcasting Corporation, James MacKay and Derek Jarman
results.brief_description:
Cinematic interpretation of Benjamin Britten’s 1961 masterly religious/poetic choral oratorio, combining the Latin Mass with several poems by the British war poet Wilfred Owen. Owen was killed on the battlefield a week before the armistice that ended WWI. Jarman merges dramatic sequences, paintings, collages and documentary footage from the wars of the 20th century to evoke the tragedy of war and the untimely death of youth. The film has been interpreted as a metaphor on the war against AIDS. A film without dialogue, featuring Olivier in his final film role.

Credits: James Mackay ; director, writer, Derek Jarman ; photography, Richard Greatrex ; editing, Rick Elgood.
Cast: Laurence Olivier, Tilda Swinton, Nathaniel Parker, Owen Teale, Nigel Terry.

results.title: War poets
results.brief_description: An informative documentary tracing the poetry that has been inspired by war and conflict from the Dark Ages through until World War I. The program focuses mainly on British poetry but is inclusive of a few works from other countries. Poetry readings are layed over dramatised re-creations of battle sequences and still photographs and comments and interpretation from academics direct the analytical features of the documentary. A performative narration also seams the themes of the program together, all combined to create a brief insight into the development of the art of war poetry over time.

results.brief_description: The frequency of wars seems to prove that they resolve nothing. results.title: War of the century
results.brief_description: War of the century is a detailed four part account of the brutal war fought between Hitler’s Germany and Soviet Russia. The devastating Second World War conflict which was instigated by Germany’s invasion of the Soviet Union left over 30 million dead, 15 million of which were civilians. Combining archival footage and first hand accounts, this engrossing documentary traces Germany’s initial victorious invasion and their ultimate defeat at Stalingrad. Although the soldier’s of the Soviet army had a life expectancy of 24 hours, the most devastating consequences of the war were exacted upon the Soviet citizens. Not only did they have to deal with the brutality of Hitler, who ordered the burning of countless villages across Russia, but their own tyrannical leader Stalin, who bore down swift retribution on anyone that defied him or the state. Meanwhile, other regions and their people felt the brunt of the war from all sides - one such region was the Ukraine. The Ukrainian’s who had been fighting for independence from the Soviet Union, ultimately found themselves at the mercy of the Germans (who they initially hoped would become their liberators), the partisans (who saw them as collaborator’s), and the Russian State (who branded them traitors). Aside from the rare archival colour footage, it’s the many moving testimonials from Russian and German survivors that bring home the horror of this war and make “War of the century” such compelling viewing. The parts of the series are: High hopes; Spiral of terror; Learning to win; Vengeance.

results.title: War in the Pacific
results.brief_description: With the attack on Peal Harbour in 1942, Prime Minister Curtin announced that Australia faced the gravest hour in her history, with the frightening possibility that war would break out on Australian soil - a fear that appeared proven when Darwin was attacked. Australian war correspondents fearlessly captured the action of Australian troops in the Pacific, and this 70 minute compilation features Movietone News and Cinesound Review of footage from campaigns in the Coral Sea, Kokoda, New Guinea, Finchaven, Burma and Milne Bay.

results.title: War II: total war
results.brief_description: A film record, suitable for schools, of the war years of 1939 to 1945, showing major developments from the rise of Nazism in Germany to the first atomic bomb at Hiroshima. It does not minimize the brutality of war, but shows how this “total war,” unlike wars of the past that engaged only the men of the fighting front, involved in varying degree almost every individual of every nation.

results.title: War generation: Beirut (D)
results.creator_credit: International Broadcasting Trust, MTC (Lebanon), BBC-TV, Jean Khalil Chamoun and Mai Masri
results.brief_description: An award winning documentary filmed by husband and wife team Jean Chamoun (Lebanese) and Mai Masri (Palestinian) which tells the story of three generations of young people whose lives have been dominated by civil war in a divided Beirut and who have become known as the “war generation”. 13-year-old Nidal does not know what peace means. Born in 1975 when the civil war began, he and many other children play games, war games, as they mimic their elders on the war-torn streets of Beirut. The city of Beirut is divided with the Christians living in East Beirut and the Muslims in West Beirut (made up of a large Palestinian and Shi-ite population) and what may have begun as a political war soon turned into a religious sectarian war. Continual bombings have destroyed much of the housing, there is no work, no schools and food is hard to come by. It would seem that most Lebanese, on both sides, are questioning this civil war. They are tired of the killing, the destruction and living in constant fear and constant danger. Through the frank and honest interviews and personal narratives contained in this documentary, we are given an unbiased, more intimate, perspective on the appalling everyday lives and struggles which took place in Lebanon during the war crisis where more than 150,000 people lost their lives, Christians and Muslims alike. Peace finally came to Beirut in 1990, although Israeli forces occupied southern Lebanon for many years on. A compelling and soul-searching documentary. Narrated by Margaret Magnusson.

results.title: War and peace = Jang aur aman
results.brief_description: Filmed over three tumultuous years in India, Pakistan, Japan and the USA, following nuclear tests in the Indian sub-continent “War and peace” documents a journey of peace activism in the face of global militarism and war. Examines the costs being extracted from citizens in the name of national security and the plight of residents living near the nuclear test site, as well as the horrendous effects of uranium mining on local indigenous populations. Filmmaker Anand Patwardhan presents ordinary Indians vying for peace and taking part in grass roots activism in light of India’s increased interest in nuclear power. He also examines the impact of American policy and the way in which American points of view (in particular ‘might is right’) has derailed the arguments about the perils of nuclear warfare. One segment is devoted to examining the legacy of Hiroshima and Nagasaki - which continue to remain contentious subjects for the US military. The Smithsonian Institute for example experienced conflict from the government when it mounted an exhibit about the after-effects of the nuclear manoeuvrings of World War 2. A post-credit sequence briefly addresses September 11 terrorist attack. This is an intelligent, insightful and important work. Awards: Grand Prize, 2002 Earth Vision Film Festival (Tokyo) ; Best Film, 2002 Mumbai International Film Festival (India) ; International Jury Prize, 2002 Mumbai International Film Festival (India) ; Critic’s Prize (FIPRESCI), 2002 Sydney International Film Festival; Best Film, 2002 Indian Documentary Producers Association’s (IDPA).
